channel.title: news on PepsFeeder
channel.description: Recent content in news on PepsFeeder

item.title: Middle East Crisis> Hezbollah Again Fires Rockets Into Northern Israel as Border Clashes Intensify
item.description: Hezbollah fired rockets into northern Israel on Tuesday, as border clashes between Israel and Lebanon intensified. The Israeli military said that the rockets were fired from southern Lebanon and landed in open areas.

item.title: Reconstruction Official Resigns, Highlighting Tensions in Ukraine
item.description: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s top official for the reconstruction of the war-torn east resigned on Tuesday, citing a lack of support from the government and a failure to secure funding for projects to rebuild the region.

item.title: At Least 49 Dead After Migrant Boat Sinks Off Yemen
item.description: At least 49 people have died after a boat carrying migrants sank off the coast of Yemen, according to the International Organization for Migration (IOM).

item.title: U.N. Passes Gaza Cease-Fire Resolution as Blinken Presses Israel and Hamas
item.description: The United Nations Security Council on Friday passed a resolution calling for a cease-fire in the Gaza conflict, as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke with Israeli and Palestinian leaders and urged an end to the violence.

item.title: Chiquita Held Liable for Deaths During Colombian Civil War
item.description: A federal judge in Florida has ruled that Chiquita Brands International, the world’s largest banana company, is liable for the deaths of four Colombian union leaders who were assassinated during the country’s civil war.

item.title: After Weeks of Planning, Seconds Made the Difference in Israel’s Hostage Rescue
item.description: By: David A. Andelman The hostage crisis in Entebbe, Uganda, in 1976 was a turning point in the history of counter-terrorism. It was the first time that a government had taken the risk of launching a rescue mission to save its citizens from terrorists.

item.title: Buoyed by Election, Meloni Basks in Spotlight as Italy Hosts G7
item.description: By Giada Zampano July 6, 2023 ROME — Giorgia Meloni, Italy’s first female prime minister, basked in the international spotlight on Thursday as she welcomed leaders from the Group of Seven nations to the ancient coastal town of Syracuse, Sicily, for a summit that was expected to focus on energy security, the global economy and China.

item.title: No, a Remote Amazon Tribe Did Not Get Addicted to Porn
item.description: ography A viral story about a remote Amazon tribe getting addicted to pornography after encountering a smartphone is not true. The story was first published in 2018 and has been debunked by multiple fact-checking organizations.

item.title: France in Shock as Conservative Leader Embraces Far Right
item.description: By JAMES KANTER and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA PARIS — François Fillon, the conservative candidate for the French presidency, has been a champion of the free market, a critic of the European Union and a defender of the French language.

item.title: As the War in Gaza Drags on, Palestinians in the West Bank Have ‘Reached Rock Bottom’
item.description: The Israeli military’s bombardment of Gaza has dominated headlines for the past week, but the conflict has also had a devastating impact on Palestinians in the West Bank.

item.title: Middle East Crisis> Israel and Hamas Signal Openness to Cease-Fire Plan, but Stop Short of Accepting It
item.description: Israel and Hamas signaled openness to a cease-fire plan proposed by Egypt, but neither side has yet accepted the plan in full, raising questions about whether a lasting truce can be reached to end the latest round of violence in the Gaza Strip.

item.title: British TV Doctor Michael Mosley Found Dead in Greece
item.description: British TV doctor Michael Mosley was found dead in Greece on Monday, according to reports. The 63-year-old, who was best known for his health and diet programs, was reportedly found dead in his hotel room in the Greek island of Ithaca.

item.title: Where New Tent Cities Are Rising in Central Gaza
item.description: By: Amira Hass The Israeli army has been destroying Palestinian homes in the Gaza Strip for 40 years. The latest wave of demolitions, which began in the summer of 2000, has left 1,500 families homeless.

item.title: Iran Names Six Candidates for President, Including Parliament Speaker
item.description: Iran’s Guardian Council, a body of clerics and jurists, has approved six candidates for the country’s presidential election on June 18, including the incumbent, Hassan Rouhani, and the parliament speaker, Ali Larijani.

item.title: Modi, Striking a Modest Tone, Is Sworn In for a Third Term
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi was sworn in for a third term on Thursday, promising to work for the “poor, the downtrodden and the marginalized” as he took the oath of office in a ceremony that was scaled back because of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Biden Visits a Military Cemetery in France That Trump Once Snubbed
item.description: President Joe Biden visited the Aisne-Marne American Cemetery and Memorial in France on Sunday, a military cemetery that former President Donald Trump skipped during a visit to the country in 2018.

item.title: Flemish Nationalists Thwart Ascent of Secessionist Party in Belgian Elections
item.description: By J. D. Longstreet The Flemish Nationalists, in Belgium, have thwarted the ascent of a secessionist party in the Belgian elections. The Flemish Nationalists, who are the largest party in the Flemish region of Belgium, have been able to keep the secessionist party, the New Flemish Alliance (N-VA), from gaining a majority in the Flemish parliament.

item.title: Middle East Crisis> Benny Gantz Quits Israel’s Emergency Government in Dispute Over Gaza
item.description: War Israel’s Defense Minister Benny Gantz resigned from the country’s emergency government on Monday, citing a dispute over the handling of the recent conflict in Gaza.

item.title: Mexico’s Leftists Won Big. Investors Are Worried.
item.description: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and ALEXANDER BURNS MEXICO CITY — The leftist Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador won Mexico’s presidential election on Sunday, a victory that could upend the country’s economic policies and shift its foreign relations, particularly with the United States.

item.title: Battered by Far Right in E.U. Vote, Macron Calls for New Elections in France
item.description: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France called on Saturday for new parliamentary elections to be held in June, after his party suffered a crushing defeat in the European Parliament elections, with the far right making significant gains.

item.title: In E.U. Elections, the Center Holds, but the Far Right Still Wreaks Havoc
item.description: The European Union’s parliamentary elections, held last week, were a test of the bloc’s resilience in the face of populist and nationalist movements. The results, while not a complete repudiation of the far right, were a clear rejection of the most extreme voices.

item.title: British Leader Apologizes for Leaving D-Day Commemoration Early
item.description: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson apologized on Tuesday for leaving a D-Day commemoration ceremony early, saying he had been suffering from a “bit of a cold.

item.title: The E.U. Is Voting. It’s Never Mattered More.
item.description: The European Union is holding its first-ever direct elections for the European Parliament. The results will determine the direction of the 27-nation bloc for the next five years.

item.title: As Fighting Rages in Ukraine, a Struggle Is On for Artillery Supremacy
item.description: The war in Ukraine has become a test of wills, with both sides trying to outmaneuver each other and gain artillery supremacy. The Ukrainian military has been using a variety of artillery systems, including the Soviet-era 122mm D-30 howitzer, the 152mm 2S3 Akatsiya self-propelled howitzer, and the 155mm M109A2 self-propelled howitzer, which was provided by the United States.

item.title: Between the Offensives> Images From a Journey in Ukraine’s Borderland
item.description: by Marko Strojin In the summer of 2014, I traveled to the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine, where a war between Ukrainian government forces and pro-Russian separatists had been raging for several months.

item.title: From the I.R.A. to the Principal’s Office, a Life’s Evolution Echoes Belfast’s
item.description: Tumult By JAMES BARRON BELFAST, Northern Ireland — The first time he was arrested, he was 16, a member of the Irish Republican Army, and he was caught with a gun.

item.title: For the First French Town Liberated on D-Day, History Is Personal
item.description: By JAMES G. NEUSS Published: June 6, 2014 Sainte-Mère-Église, France — The American paratrooper who landed here on D-Day, June 6, 1944, was supposed to be a replacement for a soldier who had been killed.

item.title: Biden Apologizes to Zelensky for Delay in U.S. Aid
item.description: to Ukraine U.S. President Joe Biden apologized to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky for the delay in providing Ukraine with military aid, the White House said in a statement on Friday.

item.title: A Careful Dance> How Hezbollah and Israel Have Kept the Lid on a Wider War
item.description: By David S. Wimberley The Middle East is a region where the most seemingly insignificant event can have far-reaching consequences. The assassination of Hezbollah leader Imad Mughniyeh in Damascus on February 12, 2008, is a case in point.

item.title: Israeli Strike Kills Dozens at Civilian Shelter in Gaza
item.description: Israeli warplanes struck a United Nations-run school in the Gaza Strip on Saturday, killing at least 15 people and wounding dozens more who had sought refuge there from the violence that has engulfed the territory, according to Palestinian health officials.

item.title: Middle East Crisis> Israel Presses Offensive in Central Gaza After Deadly Strike on Shelter
item.description: Israeli forces pressed an offensive in central Gaza on Sunday, a day after a deadly strike on a United Nations-run school sheltering Palestinians displaced by the conflict.

item.title: Biden’s New Order Leaves Migrants at Border in Limbo Over Asylum Fate
item.description: President Joe Biden’s administration is leaving migrants at the U.S.-Mexico border in limbo over the fate of asylum, as it grapples with a surge in arrivals and a court order that has blocked a key policy change.

item.title: A War on the Nile Pushes Sudan Toward the Abyss
item.description: A War on the Nile Pushes Sudan Toward the Abyss Sudanese soldiers stand guard at a checkpoint in the capital, Khartoum, on June 16, 2021. Mohamed Nureldin Abdallah/Reuters

item.title: Papua New Guinea to End Search for Landslide Victims
item.description: Papua New Guinea’s prime minister says the government will end the search for victims of a landslide that killed at least 25 people in the country’s highlands.

item.title: Train Crash in Czech Republic Kills 4 and Injures More Than 20
item.description: A train crash in the Czech Republic on Friday killed four people and injured more than 20, according to the country’s emergency services. The crash occurred at around 11:30 a.

item.title: In Global Elections, Strongmen Are Taken Down a Notch
item.description: The world is witnessing a wave of elections in which strongmen are being challenged, and in some cases, defeated. In the United States, President Donald Trump, who has been accused of authoritarian tendencies, is facing a tough re-election battle against former Vice President Joe Biden.

item.title: Bombed and Bruised, a City Braces for Another Russian Onslaught
item.description: MOSCOW — The Russian military has been pounding Ukraine’s eastern Donbas region for weeks, and now it is turning its attention to the capital, Kyiv.

item.title: Inside the Base Where Israel Has Detained Thousands of Gazans
item.description: Inside the Base Where Israel Has Detained Thousands of Gazans Israeli soldiers stand guard at the Erez crossing between Israel and the Gaza Strip on July 16, 2018.

item.title: Middle East Crisis> Israeli Airstrike on School Kills Dozens in Gaza
item.description: Israeli airstrikes on a school in Gaza killed at least 40 people, including children, on Thursday, according to Palestinian officials. The attack on the United Nations-run school in the Jabalya refugee camp was the deadliest single incident in the conflict between Israel and Hamas militants in Gaza.

item.title: Biden Will Link Fight for Ukraine With Allied Effort on D-Day
item.description: President Biden will use a speech in Normandy on Thursday to link the United States’ commitment to Ukraine with the Allied victory in World War II, arguing that the United States must continue to stand up for democracy and freedom around the world.

item.title: D-Day at 80
item.description: : The Battle of Normandy D-Day at 80: The Battle of Normandy D-Day at 80: The Battle of Normandy D-Day at 80: The Battle of Normandy

item.title: Meet the One Man Everyone Trusts on U.K. Election Nights
item.description: The BBC’s Andrew Neil is a fixture of British politics, and he’s not afraid to ask the tough questions. By Alexandra Schwartz The BBC’s Andrew Neil is a fixture of British politics, and he’s not afraid to ask the tough questions.

item.title: Needing Help to Stay in Power, Modi Loses His Aura of Invincibility
item.description: By Rakesh Raman Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who was once considered invincible, is now struggling to stay in power. Modi, who is known for his aggressive and autocratic style of governance, is facing a tough challenge from the opposition parties in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh (UP) where he is trying to win the assembly elections to be held in February 2017.

item.title: Rival U.K. Political Leaders Clash in Bad-Tempered Election Debate
item.description: LONDON—Britain’s two main political leaders clashed in a bad-tempered debate Thursday, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson accusing his Labour Party rival Jeremy Corbyn of being a Marxist who would wreck the economy and the opposition leader saying the Conservative leader was a liar.

item.title: Ukraine Strikes Into Russia With Western Weapons, Official Says
item.description: Ukraine has launched a series of strikes into Russian territory using Western-supplied weapons, a senior Ukrainian official said on Sunday, a move that could mark a significant escalation in the conflict.

item.title: Modi Struggles to Stay on Top> 4 Takeaways From India’s Election
item.description: India’s ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is struggling to maintain its majority in the country’s parliament, according to exit polls released Sunday. The polls suggest that the BJP will win between 151 and 206 seats in the 543-seat Lok Sabha, the lower house of India’s parliament, falling short of the 272 seats needed for a majority.

item.title: Middle East Crisis> Biden Suggests Netanyahu Is Prolonging War to Stay in Power
item.description: U.S. President Joe Biden has suggested that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is prolonging the conflict with Hamas in Gaza to stay in power. Biden made the remarks during a press conference on Thursday, saying that he had spoken to Netanyahu and told him that the violence had to stop.

item.title: For Heroes of D-Day, This Reunion Might Be a ‘Last Hurrah’
item.description: By JAMES BARRON Published: June 6, 2014 OMAHA BEACH, France — The men who stormed the beaches of Normandy 70 years ago are getting old, and many are dying.

item.title: What Ukraine Has Lost
item.description: What Ukraine Has Lost Ukrainian soldiers stand guard at a checkpoint in the village of Shyrokyne, near the town of Mariupol, on Feb. 18, 2015. AP Photo/Evgeniy Maloletka

item.title: Modi Claims 3rd Term in India, but His Party Suffers Losses
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu nationalist party won a third term in India’s general election, but it suffered its worst-ever losses in the vote, according to preliminary results.

item.title: Gazans Pin Hopes on New Truce Proposal, but Remain Skeptical
item.description: By JONATHAN S. Landay McClatchy Newspapers GAZA CITY, Gaza Strip — The residents of Gaza are pinning their hopes on a new truce proposal, but they remain skeptical that it will bring an end to the Israeli military offensive that has killed more than 1,000 Palestinians and displaced tens of thousands more.

item.title: A Surging Hard Right in Europe Stumbles Over Its Own Divisions
item.description: The European Union is facing a crisis of legitimacy, with the rise of populist, nationalist parties that are challenging the very foundations of the bloc. These parties, which have gained significant ground in recent years, are united by their opposition to immigration, their skepticism of globalization, and their rejection of the EU’s institutions and values.

item.title: Claudia Sheinbaum Makes History as First Woman Elected to Lead Mexico
item.description: City Claudia Sheinbaum, a 56-year-old engineer and former head of the city’s environmental department, won the election for mayor of Mexico City on Sunday, making her the first woman to lead the capital in its 230-year history.

item.title: Another Milestone in Mexico> Its First Jewish President
item.description: By: Yair Rosenberg On July 1, 2018, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, a left-wing populist, was sworn in as the president of Mexico. He is the first Jewish president in the country’s history.

item.title: What to Know About Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico’s Newly Elected President
item.description: Claudia Sheinbaum, a 56-year-old engineer and former cabinet member, has been elected as Mexico’s new president. She is the first woman to hold the position and is expected to take office on December 1.

item.title: Floods Break Dams and Submerge Highways in Southern Germany
item.description: Floods in southern Germany have broken dams and submerged highways, as the region grapples with the worst flooding in more than a century. The German government has declared a disaster in the state of Bavaria, where at least 13 people have died and hundreds more are missing.

item.title: Jacob Zuma Gets His Revenge on South African Party That Shunned Him
item.description: Jacob Zuma, the former president of South Africa, has been a polarizing figure since he took office in 2009. His tenure was marked by allegations of corruption, economic mismanagement, and a disregard for the rule of law.

item.title: Mexico Joins List of Latin American Nations That Have Elected Female Presidents
item.description: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s leftist presidential candidate, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, won a landslide victory on Sunday, ending seven decades of rule by the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, and ushering in a new era of politics in Latin America’s second-largest economy.

item.title: Brexit Champion Says He’ll Run for Parliament, Jolting U.K. Election
item.description: Boris Johnson, the former foreign secretary who has been a leading advocate for Britain leaving the European Union, said on Monday that he would run for Parliament in a by-election in a northern English constituency, a move that could complicate the political landscape in the country.

item.title: Netanyahu May Face a Choice Between a Truce and His Government’s Survival
item.description: Netanyahu May Face a Choice Between a Truce and His Government’s Survival Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is facing a difficult choice: whether to accept a ceasefire with Hamas or risk the collapse of his government.

item.title: Middle East Crisis> Israel’s Military Says 4 More Hostages in Gaza Are Dead, Killed Months Ago
item.description: Israel’s military said on Sunday that four more hostages held by Hamas in the Gaza Strip were dead, killed months ago, and that the militant group was lying about their condition.

item.title: Blinken Hints U.S. May Allow Ukraine Greater Latitude to Strike in Russia
item.description: -Controlled Territories U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken hinted on Sunday that the United States may allow Ukraine greater latitude to strike at targets in Russia-controlled territories, as the war in Ukraine enters its second year.

item.title: A Matter of Survival as South Asia’s Heat Wave Reaches 127 Degrees
item.description: Fahrenheit The heat wave that has been sweeping across South Asia has reached its peak, with temperatures in Pakistan and India reaching 127 degrees Fahrenheit (53 degrees Celsius) in some areas.

item.title: After Trump’s Conviction, a Wary World Waits for the Fallout
item.description: The verdict in the impeachment trial of former President Donald J. Trump was a foregone conclusion. The question now is what it means for the United States and the world.

item.title: On Northern Border, Permission to Fire Into Russia Buoys Ukraine
item.description: By ANDREW E. KRAMER KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s military has been given permission to fire into Russia if it is attacked, a senior Ukrainian official said on Tuesday, a move that could escalate tensions between the two countries.

item.title: How Rhubarb Conquered Germany, Then the World
item.description: Rhubarb is a plant that has been cultivated for centuries, but it wasn’t until the 19th century that it became popular in Germany. The plant was initially brought to Europe from China, and it was used primarily for medicinal purposes.

item.title: Deepfake of U.S. Official Appears After Shift on Ukraine Attacks in Russia
item.description: Probe A deepfake video of a U.S. official appeared online after the Justice Department said it would no longer prosecute two Ukrainian officials accused of tampering with the 2016 election.

item.title: Israel Pushes Deeper Into Rafah, but Gaza Exit Plan Remains Unclear
item.description: By JANE PERLEZ Published: October 2, 2004 GAZA CITY, Gaza Strip, Oct. 1 - Israeli troops pushed deeper into the Rafah refugee camp on Friday, as the Israeli government continued to debate a plan to withdraw from the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.

item.title: A Small Army Combating a Flood of Deepfakes in India’s Election
item.description: The Indian government has deployed a small army of fact-checkers to combat a flood of deepfakes during the country’s general election, which began on Thursday.

item.title: Middle East Crisis Biden Outlines Cease-fire Proposal to End War in Gaza
item.description: President Joe Biden on Thursday outlined a cease-fire proposal to end the war in Gaza, saying he spoke with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas about the plan.

item.title: Musk accuses Biden of lying about the immigration crisis
item.description: The billionaire and American businessman, Elon Musk, accused the American president on Sunday of lying about the immigration crisis, stating that President Joe Biden’s remarks about wanting to solve the issue of illegal immigration are “pure lies.

item.title: Supporting Israel causes losses to America
item.description: The war waged by the Israeli occupation on the Gaza Strip continues to claim more casualties among civilians and children, in light of the growing voices across the world demanding a truce and an immediate end to one of the largest massacres committed in Palestine.

item.title: UAP and classified aerospace platforms
item.description: The increasing difficulty to manage deterrence Deterrence is simple in principle and a natural strategy to adopt. But when deterrence relies on new advanced weapons of which your adversaries ignores everything it is not so straightforward when it comes to implementation.

item.title: Joint Pain How Can I Keep My Joints Healthy
item.description: You’ve probably heard that regular exercise can decrease your risk of Type 2 diabetes, heart disease and stroke. But did you know that regular exercise can improve your joint health?

item.title: Advanced cohesive information warfare
item.description: Advanced cohesive information warfare evilware is any piece of software that is neither a virus nor spyware, and has no damaging effect on a computer system, but it has a devastating evil effect on society.

item.title: Wiretapping under the 46th Presidency
item.description: To rule is the exercise of control on the basis of knowledge Surveillance is one of the forces that enable social organization. The era of the information society is the age of over-penetrating bureaucracy, to such an extent that simply to participate in modern society is to be under electronic surveillance.

item.title: Trump chances of winning the election are diminishing
item.description: The American newspaper “The Hill” published on its website an article by writer Niall Stanig in which he affirmed that President Donald Trump’s chances of winning a second term are diminishing, while opinion polls indicate that his Democratic opponent, Joe Biden, has advanced by a large margin that is difficult for him to overcome.

item.title: Seven questions about negative oil prices
item.description: While Ukrainians rested after the celebration of Easter, the world collapsed in the oil markets. First, on Black Monday, oil collapsed to zero, and then buyers of American oil were paid extra for taking it.

item.title: South Korean officials: There is no indication that Kim Jong-un is experiencing physical problems
item.description: According to a media report on Tuesday (April 21), North Korean leader Kim Jong-un was seriously ill, leading to a sharp depreciation of South Korean currency and the South Korean stock market.

item.title: Trump vs Fauci: President and doctor spar over unproven drug
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — In an extraordinary exchange, President Donald Trump and the government’s top infectious disease expert, Dr. Anthony Fauci, publicly sparred Friday on whether a malaria drug would work to treat people with coronavirus disease.

item.title: US virus testing faces new headwind: Lab supply shortages
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — First, some of the coronavirus tests didn’t work. Then there weren’t enough to go around. Now, just as the federal government tries to ramp up nationwide screening, laboratory workers are warning of a new roadblock: dire shortages of testing supplies.

item.title: Italy's virus epicenter grapples with huge toll, some hidden
item.description: BERGAMO, Italy (AP) — The priest gave a final benediction. There were no flowers, no embraces. Francesca Steffanoni and her mother hurried away from Bergamo’s main cemetery, their furtive farewell lasting no more than 5 minutes.

item.title: Asian stocks rise after Wall Street advance on aid hopes
item.description: BEIJING (AP) — Asian stock markets rose Friday after Wall Street gained on hopes government and central bank action can shield the world economy from a looming recession caused by the coronavirus.

item.title: Joe Biden, nominee-in-waiting. And waiting. And waiting.
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — In the three weeks since his blowout win in the South Carolina primary, Joe Biden has emerged as the Democratic presidential nominee-in-waiting. But, amid the uncertainty of the coronavirus pandemic, put the emphasis on waiting.

item.title: Europeans sing health workers' praises nightly from windows
item.description: PARIS (AP) — At a time of isolation, people in many European cities hit hard by the new coronavirus are taking at least a minute each night to come together in gratitude.

item.title: Gabbard ends long-shot 2020 bid, throws support to Biden
item.description: COLUMBIA, S.C. (AP) — Hawaii Rep. Tulsi Gabbard suspended her presidential campaign on Thursday, ending a long-shot effort that saw her feuding with Hillary Clinton and raising fears among Democrats that she would mount a third-party 2020 bid.

item.title: Israel's Netanyahu accused of exploiting virus crisis
item.description: JERUSALEM (AP) — With the Israeli government enacting a series of emergency measures to stem the spread of the new coronavirus, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is facing growing accusations that he is exploiting the crisis to entrench himself in power and undermining the country’s democratic foundations.

item.title: Indonesia halts Islamic assembly, quarantining 9,000 people
item.description: MAKASSAR, Indonesia (AP) — Indonesia halted a mass congregation of nearly 9,000 Muslim pilgrims and began quarantining and checking their health Thursday to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus.

item.title: Trump dubs COVID-19 ‘Chinese virus' despite hate crime risks
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — President Donald Trump said Wednesday that he doesn’t think calling COVID-19 the “Chinese virus” — or the “kung-flu,” as one administration official reportedly called it — puts Asian Americans at risk of retaliation despite growing reports they are facing virus-related discrimination.

item.title: Public debut without public for polar bear cubs at Dutch zoo
item.description: THE HAGUE, Netherlands (AP) — A pair of twin polar bear cubs have made their public debut at a Dutch zoo — but without the public because of coronavirus restrictions.

item.title: Clean water access for India's poor spawns virus concerns
item.description: NEW DELHI (AP) — Dharam Singh Rajput can’t afford to buy hand sanitizer, which could help ward off transmission of the coronavirus in his community.

item.title: Watchdog says Israel's West Bank settlements surged in 2019
item.description: JERUSALEM (AP) — Israeli settlement activity in the West Bank surged ahead in 2019, a watchdog group said in a report Tuesday, maintaining a rapid pace that has drawn strength from the friendly policies of the Trump administration.

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic leads Amazon to ban many non-essential items
item.description: Faced with merchandise shortages in the United States and Europe due to the Covid-19 coronavirus pandemic, Amazon has instituted sweeping changes on which products it will store and ship from its warehouses over the next three weeks, in a move it said was aimed at keeping essential items in stock and speeding up orders.

item.title: A cruel paradox: Beating virus means causing US recession
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — No one knows how long it will last or how much it will hurt. But the U.S. economy is either sliding into a recession for the first time since 2009 or is already in one — a sudden victim of the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Spreading birthday card love in the time of coronavirus
item.description: NEW YORK (AP) — Mona Helgeland was sad for her children. Their birthdays were coming up but they were self-quarantined because of the coronavirus and going to miss celebrating with friends and family.

item.title: Dear Corona Diary: German patient gives updates on Twitter
item.description: BERLIN (AP) — On the fifth day after she fell ill with COVID-19 respiratory disease, Karoline Preisler could breathe again without wincing through severe pain in her chest.

item.title: Coronavirus news is dominating readers' attention
item.description: If you feel like you’ve been glued to the news lately, you’re not alone. We’re collectively reading much more news during the novel coronavirus pandemic than normal, according to new publisher traffic data.

item.title: Cinemas close nationwide, studios push new movies into homes
item.description: NEW YORK (AP) — U.S. movie theaters have closed nationwide due to the coronavirus pandemic, turning dark nearly all of the country’s 40,000-plus screens in an unprecedented shutdown.

item.title: The Health Department website was attacked in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic
item.description: The US Health and Human Services Department was the victim of a cyberattack yesterday, the agency confirmed to Recode. Bloomberg, which was first to report the attack on Monday morning, initially described it as a hack, but updates to its story removed the word “hack,” instead referring to it as “multiple incidents of a cyber intrusion.

item.title: Sex workers face ruin amid virus fears, brothel closures
item.description: BERLIN (AP) — It’s 7 p.m. on a Friday night, a time when Aurel Johannes Marx’s three-room brothel on the edge of Berlin would normally be preparing for its first customers.

item.title: With borders and businesses closing, world hunkers down
item.description: BANGKOK (AP) — With borders slamming shut, schools and businesses closing and increasingly drastic restrictions on movement, tens of millions of people were hunkered down Tuesday, heeding government calls to isolate themselves and slow the spread of the new coronavirus.

item.title: With 208th song on Hot 100 chart, Drake sets new record
item.description: NEW YORK (AP) — Drake has landed his 208th song on the Billboard Hot 100 chart, setting a new record for most songs on the music chart.

item.title: Coronavirus means The Hunt and Trolls get early streaming rental options
item.description: You can’t go to the movies. So some movies are going to come to you. That’s the message from media giant NBCUniversal, whose movie studio is going to start letting customers rent a selection of movies that are supposed to be in theaters now.

item.title: Virus fears fuel spike in sales of guns and ammunition
item.description: BOISE, Idaho (AP) — The world’s largest gun store, in metro Atlanta, has had lines that are six and eight people deep. A gun store in Los Angeles had lines that stretched down the block.

item.title: How coronavirus is affecting the restaurant business, in one chart
item.description: In addition to its severe cost to human life, the novel coronavirus has wreaked havoc on a number of industries including airlines, cruises, and conferences. As people and governments and public health experts stress the importance of social distancing as a way to stem the spread of the contagion, restaurants are seeing major declines in patronage.

item.title: US officials: Foreign disinformation stoking virus fears
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — The Trump administration is alleging that a foreign disinformation campaign is underway aimed at spreading fear in the country amid the coronavirus pandemic, three U.

item.title: Virus toll in Iran climbs as lockdowns deepen across Mideast
item.description: TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran reported another 129 fatalities from the new coronavirus on Monday, the largest one-day rise in deaths since it began battling the Middle East’s worst outbreak, which has claimed more than 850 lives and infected a number of senior officials in the country.

item.title: Google's coronavirus website isn't what Trump described

item.title: After targeting sites in Syria, Israel is preparing for an Iranian strike

item.title: Saudi Aramco loses $ 2 billion in oil production
